abstract:
In this study, researchers aimed to explore the use of environmental DNA (eDNA) testing for detecting New Zealand mudsnails (Potamopyrgus antipodarum) in an early and efficient manner. To do so, they collected water filter samples from two locations in the Portneuf River in Idaho. The Portneuf River is a 5th-order river, spanning approximately 150 km long, with a drainage basin of 3445 km2. This human-altered and eutrophic river has high nutrient and sediment loads (Marcarelliet al.2009).

The necessity of using eDNA tests lies in their ability to detect the presence of specific organisms, such as New Zealand mudsnails, in water samples without the need to physically capture the animals. Traditional methods of identification can be time-consuming and labor-intensive. In contrast, eDNA testing is a quicker, more efficient alternative for monitoring aquatic species populations.

The researchers collected water filter samples using unspecified methods. The samples were then processed to extract any DNA present in the water. This extracted DNA was amplified through Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) technology, allowing the researchers to identify the presence of New Zealand mudsnail eDNA. If the eDNA was detected, it would indicate the presence of live New Zealand mudsnails in the sample.

This method solves several issues raised when using traditional methods for monitoring New Zealand mudsnail populations in the Portneuf River. Traditional methods are labor-intensive and time-consuming, making them less efficient for large-scale monitoring efforts. Additionally, these methods can be less accurate as they rely on physically capturing animals, which may not always be present or easily identifiable. In contrast, eDNA testing is a quicker, more reliable alternative that allows for the detection of specific organisms without the need to physically capture them.

Two field sites were selected from the Portneuf River, which is a 5th-order river stretching approximately 150 km from its source to its confluence with the Snake River. The basin area of the Portneuf River encompasses 3445 kmÂ².

To collect water filter samples, we visited sites located near Pocatello, Idaho. The Portneuf River is characterized as a human-altered, eutrophic river with elevated nutrient and sediment loads, as reported by Marcarelliet et al. (2009). This environmental condition could potentially impact the detection of New Zealand mudsnails using eDNA tests.

The eDNA test is a molecular method that involves filtering water samples to capture any shed DNA from organisms present in the water. In this study, we did not specify the exact filtration system or methods used for collecting the water samples or filtering the water. The collected water filter samples underwent further processing and analysis, likely involving extraction of the eDNA using techniques such as silica-based columns or magnetic beads. The PCR products were then subjected to capillary electrophoresis or other suitable downstream techniques for species identification and quantification based on the size, shape, or fluorescence patterns of the resulting fragments.
